moves.1. e4: My opponent started with e4. This is my only opening if I play white.
moves.1... e5: My usual response to e4. I don't know much about opening and and still trying to learn the basics.
moves.2. Nf3 Nc6 3. Bc4 Nf6 4. d3 Bc5: So far, both sides have developed King side and prepared to castle.
moves.5. Bg5: Pinning my knight and developed his bishop.
moves.5... d6: Supporting my pawn on e5 and preparing my LSB to get into action.
moves.6. h3: I've encountered this move so many times after this game and started to think that this is a very good move as it preventing my bishop or my knight on g4. But i don't usually play this move.
moves.6... O-O 7. O-O Nd4: Both sides castled and the objective of Nd4 is after Nxd4, I recaptured his knight with my bishop and attacking the unprotected b2.
moves.8. Nxd4: Here, I took a long time thinking about Bxd4. I was thinking after c3, my bishop will have to go back to c5 and I'm considering exd4. Of course exd4 is not a good move as it will block my attack on the f2 and my DSB will trap on the other half of the board from his king.
moves.8... exd4: But i played it anyway thinking that I will have time to bring my DSB soon to the king side. I really should've played Bxe4.
moves.9. Qf3: When he played this move, I know that he is planning to exchange queen.
moves.10. Bxf6 Qxf6 11. Qxf6 gxf6: Now, my king is exposed and I have double f-pawns while his bishop attacking the f7.
moves.12... Kh8: Planning to bring my rook to the open g-file and allign it with his king.
moves.13. Nf3 Rg8: Now my f7 pawn is hanging and after Bxf7, my rook on g8 will be under attack. But he saw the threat Bxh3.
moves.14... h5: Attacking the pawn and trying to open a way to his king.
moves.15. Bxf7: Finally, he took the pawn. Now my pawn structure is a mess and my DSB is still trapped on the other side. I want to play Rg7 but I saw the threat Bxh5 will completely destroy my plan. So, I decided to play more aggresive.
moves.15... Bxg4: Sac my rook and threatening his knight.
moves.16. Bxg8: He took the rook. Computer analysis showed that this is a blunder and suggested white to play hxg4. And computer analysis also suggested that I play Bxf3. But I was thinking, if I played that move, his bishop can retreat and guarded the g8 square. I want to bring my rook to g8. So, I decided to play another move.
moves.16... Bxh3: Blunder, as per computer analysis. My plan here is threatening his rook and after he move his rook, I will take his bishop with my rook and controlling the g-file.
moves.17. Rfd1 Rxg8+: Now, the battle of two rooks vs two bishops begins.
moves.18. Kh2 Bg4: Attacking his knight and aiming for his rook on d1.
moves.19. Kg3: Protecting his knight. My DSB has been trapped for quite some time and I'm planning to bring it to the battlefield.
moves.19... f5 20. exf5 Bxf5+ 21. Kh4 d5 22. R: Kxh5 will lose a knight. Proposed to trade my last rook.
moves.22... Bg4: Be7+ will come to the same result.
moves.23. Ng5 Be7 24. f4 Kg7: His passed pawn on f4 is unprotected. I think it's time for my king to join the battle.
moves.25. Rae1 Bf6: Attacking my bishop and I just move it away, still keeping the pin on his knight.
moves.26. c3: Starting from this move and the next 5 moves, computer suggested white to play Rxg4 but he didn't. White could have a good game if he made that move, I think.
moves.26... dxc3 27. bxc3 Kh6: I have time to play dxc3 before moving my king.
moves.28. d4: Maybe to protect his c3 pawn which I have no intention to play. I still don't want to give up my pin on his knight. When I saw this position, I saw potential mate. If I can bring my rook to h3, I'll win. So, that is my next target.
moves.28... Rd8: E-file is protected by his rook. The only way is through the d-file.
moves.29. Rg3: Rg3?? That is the only square his king can move. Playing his rook there was not a very good move. Now, I have another mate option. If I remove his unprotected pawn on f4, Bxg5 is mate. I can still play my rook on h2 which also lead to mate.
moves.29... c5: Pawn sac to open the d-file.
moves.33. Rxg4: Finally, he made this move but it's a little too late. My rook already on f4. This move also came with a message from him said "You got me.. :)". It also ended the battle of two rooks vs two bishops.
moves.35. Rh8+ Kg6: My king laughed all the way to g6.
moves.36. Rb8 Be3: The only logical move, I think.
moves.37. Rxb7 Bxc5 38. Rc7 Bb6: Now my bishop and my a-pawn is untouchable.
moves.40... Rd3+ 41. Kg2 Rd2+ 42. Kf3 Rxa2: Eliminating his last chance of queening.
moves.43. Re1 h4: A diversion. My plan is to queen the a-pawn.
moves.44. Kg4 Ra4+ 45. Kh3 Kh5 46. Re5+ Kg6 47: Blunder!! I've waited for this move for so long.
